16.  Market Opportunities. With a rapidly growing population,3 the domestic demand for fruit 
and  vegetables  and  their  processed  products  is  expanding,  which  presents  an  opportunity  for 
producers and processors. The income elasticity of fruits ranges across income groups, but on 
average is high enough to sustain an annual growth in demand of about 8%, given the current 
annual  population  growth  rate  of  1.9%,  and  GDP  growth  rate  of  6.4%.  Income  elasticities  for 
vegetables  and  fresh  milk  are  lower  than  fruits,  but  still  significantly  positive,  and  support  an 
estimated  annual  growth  in  demand  of  about  6%.  The  income  elasticities  for  processed  fruits, 
vegetables,  and  milk  products  are  much  higher,  and  result  in  annual  increases  in  demand  in 
excess of 10% on average, indicating a sizeable potential market for domestic processors.  
 
 
17. 
The major commercial fruits with a strong domestic demand are apples, apricots, dates, 
citrus  (mainly  kinnow),  guavas,  grapes,  mangoes,  peaches,  and  plums.  The  major  vegetable 
crops  are  chili,  carrot,  cauliflower,  onion,  potato,  and  tomato.  The  market  for  fruit  juices,  fruit-
based  drinks,  and  tomato  ketchup  is  expanding  rapidly,  at  about  15–20%  annually.  The 
production  for  horticultural  products  is  highly  seasonal.  In  addition,  large  price  variations  and 
cyclic trends lead to fruit and vegetable imports, creating opportunities for import substitution.  
 
18. 
From 1999–2003, the top 10 horticultural export products based on export earnings by 
value  were  dates  (dried),  kinnow,  onions,  mangoes,  pine  nuts,  potatoes,  mushrooms,  dates 
(fresh),  chilies  (powder),  and  cumin  seed.  Annual  fruit  and  vegetable  exports  have  recently 
grown by 32%, except for fresh dates, which have declined by 10.6% per annum, indicating the 
potential  for  further  exploitation  of  world  demand  for  horticulture  products.  In  Pakistan’s  main 
fruit and vegetable export markets, the country’s export market share is less than 1%, except for 
Dubai  and  Afghanistan.  Horticulture  exports  to  the  leading  markets  of  the  European  Union, 
North  America,  and  Japan  are  miniscule,  indicating  the  need  to  remove  the  constraints  to 
penetrating  these  markets.  Floriculture  is  a  relatively  new  subsector  even  in  the  domestic 
market, with a growth potential of at least 10%. The world trade in flowers is around $30 billion, 
while  Pakistan’s  annual  floriculture  exports  are  only  about  $2  million.  While  the  markets  are 
competitive, opportunities do exist, and importers are continually seeking new products.  
 
19. 
Annual  per  capita  consumption  of  fresh  milk  is  estimated  at  72  kilograms,  leading  to  a 
fresh  milk  demand  in  2002  of  about  10.0  million  tons,  which  is  expected  to  increase  to  an 
estimated 12.8 million tons by 2010, assuming fresh milk consumption trends remain constant. 
Nearby countries such as the People’s Republic of China and Russian Federation are expected 
to experience 40% growth in milk demand by 2008. Both domestic and regional export market 
opportunities therefore exist. 
 
20. 
The  private  sector  is  increasingly  involved  in  slaughterhouses.  Per  capita  meat 
consumption is expected to rise by 290% by 2020, with red meat production not keeping pace 
with demand. The Gulf States have relaxed their trade restrictions on the export of livestock and 
livestock products from Pakistan, and the Afghan market has opened up. If slaughterhouses can 
get  easier  access  to  better  quality  and  healthier  stock  through  direct  purchasing  from  farmers 
grouped  in  fattening  associations,  and  the  raw  material  can  be  traced,  this  subsector  could 
expand rapidly.

A. 

Rationale    

AGRIBUSINESS SUPPORT FUND 
 

In  many  countries,  access  to  effective  business  development  services  (BDS)  has 
1. 
catalyzed enhanced enterprise productivity and profitability. In Pakistan, technical, managerial, 
marketing, financial, and legal advisory services are limited and, in the context of agribusiness, 
almost nonexistent. Services that do exist have tended to be in the public sector and have not 
performed  well  because  of  a  lack  of  policy  direction,  management  and  staff  capacity,  service 
marketing,  and  adequate  financing.  As  a  result,  choice  in  the  BDS  market  is  limited  as  the 
private sector has effectively been prevented from entering the market by uncompetitive service 
pricing by public sector entities. Public sector research and extension services have also been 
largely unresponsive to the needs of private sector agribusiness enterprises. These supply-side 
constraints are exacerbated by a lack of demand on the part of some agribusiness enterprises, 
which  have  yet  to  appreciate  the  benefits  of  BDS,  and  have  limited  choice  of  competitively 
priced services to meet their business development needs. 
 
2. 
BDS  related  to  agribusiness  need  to  be  developed.  One  approach,  which  has  worked 
effectively  for  small  and  medium  enterprises  (SMEs)  in  other  developing  countries,  is  to 
establish  a  time-bound  cost-sharing  grant  scheme  that  provides  support  to  BDS  providers  in 
developing  and  upgrading  the  type  of  service  they  are  able  to  offer  to  business  clients,  and 
supports agribusiness enterprises to access such services. This approach has been adopted in 
the  Small  and  Medium  Enterprise  Sector  Development  Program  financed  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). It will also be adopted in the proposed Project.  
 
B. 

Scope 

3. 
The Project will establish and fund on a grant basis an agribusiness support fund (ASF) 
to provide matching funds to finance a range of capacity-building services aimed at increasing 
enterprise  productivity  and  profitability,  and  at  facilitating  enterprise  startups.  ASF  funding  will 
also be available for demand-driven research and extension services that will lead to increased 
and  better  quality  production,  improved  production  processes,  or  meet  an  identified  market 
demand. To support enterprises in sourcing such services, ASF grants will also be available to 
BDS providers to enhance their capacity to deliver effective services to agro-enterprise clients. 
Finally,  the  ASF  will  also  cooperate  with  rural  support  programs  (RSPs)  to  support  individual 
farmers and farmers’ groups to form legally registered agribusiness enterprises that will then be 
able  to  access  ASF  support  for  other  eligible  services.  Eligible  enterprises  will  be  required  to 
finance  50%  of  the  cost  of  the  services  they  employ,  the  remaining  50%  being  contributed  by 
the  ASF  as  a  grant.  To  facilitate  the  development  of  small  farmers  into  agribusiness  ASF 
funding  will  be  available  to  only  finance  100%  of  the  costs  of  farmers’  enterprise  formation. 
Funds  will  not  be  available  for  the  financing  of  capital  equipment.  The  life  of  the  ASF  is 
intentionally designed to be temporary, ending upon project completion, to achieve a one-time, 
and  sustainable  increase  in  the  capacity  and  supply  of  BDS  to  agribusiness.  However,  other 
options  may  be  considered  if  continuation  of  the  ASF  beyond  the  project’s  completion  date  is 
deemed advisable. 
 

 

  

Appendix 4        

31

C. 

Establishment, Management, and Operation 

1. 

Establishment 

ASF  activities  will  be  overseen  by  a  board  of  directors  comprising  eight  directors,  of 
4. 
which  at  least  five  will  be  from  the  private  sector,  with  a  maximum  of  three  directors  from  the 
public sector, to be nominated by the Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Livestock (MINFAL). All 
board members will be respected individuals from the private and public sectors, acting in their 
individual capacities, rather than as representatives of particular organizations. Governance and 
management  structures  and  operating  procedures  will  broadly  follow  those  of  the  Business 
Support  Fund  (BSF)  of  the  Small  and  Medium  Enterprise  Sector  Development  Program 
(detailed  in  paras.  5-18).  ASF  structure  and  operation  will  benefit  from  experience  gained  in 
operating  the  BSF  prior  to  project  implementation  and  may,  as  a  result,  change  prior  to  its 
establishment.  
 
5. 
The ASF will be incorporated within 9 months of loan effectiveness. MINFAL will act as 
the Implementing Agency for the ASF until its incorporation, when it will become independent of 
government.  Prior  to  loan  effectiveness,  a  small-scale  technical  assistance  will  be  used  to 
support MINFAL prepare the ASF articles of association and the process of incorporation. The 
technical assistance consultant will also prepare a preliminary work plan and standard operating 
procedures  for  the  ASF,  develop  criteria  for  staff  qualifications  and  experience,  and  develop 
eligibility  criteria  for  grant  recipients  and  services  to  be  supported.  Eligibility  criteria  for  ASF 
funding applications and ASF operating procedures will be subject to approval by the ASF board 
of  directors.  A  full-time  manager  with  recognized  international  experience  managing  similar 
funds will be recruited by MINFAL subject to the approval of ADB. Given the innovative nature 
of the ASF in supporting agribusiness development, ASF applications will initially be restricted to 
develop  experience  in  the  effective  appraisal  and  processing  of  applications.  The  phased 
expansion of ASF operations will be reflected in staff recruitment.  
 
 
 
6. 
The ASF management will be responsible for finalizing the work plan, standard operating 
procedures,  and  recipient  and  service  eligibility  criteria;  and  for  recruiting  ASF  staff.  Three 
national  financial  analysts,  who  will  each  be  responsible  for  a  portfolio  of  applications  and 
grants,  will  support  the  manager.  Additional  financial  analysts  and  technical  specialists  will  be 
employed as required based on the volume and type of applications received. Financial analysts 
will  primarily  be  responsible  for  the  initial  screening  and  review  of  funding  applications  and 
monitoring  the  implementation  of  projects  and  activities  supported  by  the  ASF.  An  appraisal 
panel will be established within the ASF to appraise all applications for ASF funding. The ASF 
manager  will  chair  the  appraisal  panel,  which  comprise  four  additional  part-time  members 
recruited  by  the  ASF  manager  and  approved  by  the  board  of  directors.  As  necessary,  the 
appraisal  panel  may  request  the  ASF  to  contract  individuals  from  relevant  private  or  public 
sector institutions as consultants where an expert technical opinion may be required to properly 
evaluate an application. The ASF will also employ a farmer enterprise formation coordinator to 
be  responsible  for  overseeing  the  operation  of  participating  RSPs  in  implementing  the  farmer 
group enterprise formation. A supervision officer will be engaged to monitor and supervise the 
utilization of ASF funds by grant recipients. All ASF staff and facilities will be financed entirely 
from the proceeds of the project loan.  
 
 
 

Management 

2.

3. 

Funding Application Eligibility and Processing 

 
 
7. 
Any service that leads to outputs for a new, specifically identified market or that develops 
new  products  or  adds  value  to  existing  products  will  be  eligible  for  ASF  funding.  Proposals 
aimed at increasing production alone will not be eligible. Proposals considered by the ASF staff 
to  have  potentially  serious  environmental  risks  associated  with  their  implementation  will  be 
required  to  undertake  an  environmental  assessment.  For  this  purpose,  ASF  staff  will  refer  the 
applicant to the project management unit (PMU), which will engage an appropriate consultant or 
service provider using project funds allocated for this purpose. Guidelines for use by ASF staff 
in referring proposals for an environmental assessment will be formulated as part of the project 
environmental management plan. 
 
All applicants will be required to identify quantitative or qualitative verifiable outputs that 
8. 
will result from the receipt of ASF support, and the means of verification, both of which will be 
agreed with the ASF prior to disbursement of a grant. ASF grants will in general be subject to a 
ceiling of $25,000 equivalent (representing a total cost for the service to be funded of $50,000). 
In  exceptional  circumstances  where  benefits  are  widespread  or  where  multiplier  effects  are 
obvious (for instance for private sector research and extension), the ASF will provide grants in 
excess of this amount. All applications for grants in excess of the $25,000 ceiling will require the 
approval of the board of directors. An individual enterprise will be eligible to receive more than 
one grant but the maximum amount payable to a single recipient will be $100,000.  
 
9. 
Funding  proposals  will  be  submitted  in  standard  application  forms  to  the  ASF  either 
directly by the applicant or through project implementation agencies. In the latter case, the role 
of such agencies will be restricted to supporting applicants in the application process. They will 
not  be  permitted  to  act  as  intermediaries  or  representatives  for  applicants  with  the  ASF,  or 
participate  in  the  management  or  implementation  of  activities  supported  by  an  ASF  grant. 
Applications  will  be  handled  strictly  on  a  first-come,  first-served  basis.  ASF  financial  analysts 
under supervision of the ASF manager will undertake an initial review of each application and 
prepare  necessary  documentation  relating  to  eligible  applications  for  submission  to  the 
appraisal  panel.  The  appraisal  panel  will  meet  on  a  monthly  basis  as  a  minimum,  or  more 
frequently as determined by the ASF manager according to the number of applications received. 
The  appraisal  panel  will  reach  a  decision  on  each  application  presented  to  its  meeting  but  in 
certain  circumstances  may  request  additional  information  to  evaluate  properly  an  application. 
The decision of the panel on all applications will be final.  
 
Once an application has been approved, a funding agreement will be drawn up between 
10. 
the  ASF  and  the  grant  recipient,  who  will  be  required  to  demonstrate  the  availability  of  the 
matching  contribution.  Based  on  recipient  preference,  grants  will  be  paid  either  on  a 
reimbursable basis once satisfactory documentation detailing eligible expenditures by the grant 
recipient has been received and approved by the ASF, or in advance of such expenditures on 
condition  that  the  recipient  provides  a  bank  or  personal  guarantee  in  favor  of  ASF  for  the 
amount of the grant on terms and conditions acceptable to ASF. Where the service in question 
is to be provided over an extended period in clearly identified separate phases, funding will be 
paid in an appropriate number of tranches. As part of the funding agreement between the ASF

AGRIBUSINESS FINANCE DEVELOPMENT 

A. 

Rationale 

1. 
While lending to agriculture is increasing, in terms of the overall level of demand market 
penetration is limited. A financing gap of almost PRs167 billion ($2.8 billion) has been identified. 
Commercial banks that claim to have embarked on agriculture and agribusiness credit tend to 
restrict  lending  to  financing  of  seasonal  production  (70–75%  of  all  loans)  with  the  balance  for 
development lending. Development lending is itself largely limited to on-farm investments such 
as tractors, tube wells, and farm equipment. Lending to agribusiness, other than for large-scale 
food and beverage enterprises, is almost nonexistent. At the lower end of the market, potential 
sources  of  financing  include  recently  established  formal  microfinance  institutions  and  rural 
support programs offering credit services, although the loan ceilings and relative inexperience of 
these  institutions  (especially  in  agribusiness  lending)  limit  the  type  and  size  of  enterprise  that 
they are able to serve. Therefore, a substantial gap remains in the financing of agribusinesses 
that operate on a scale between the large-scale enterprises served by commercial banks, and 
microenterprises  that  may  be  served  by  microfinance  institutions.  Most  institutions  still  see 
agribusiness  as  a  high  risk  sector  characterized  by  high  historical  levels  of  loan  default.  This, 
and  the  fact  that  many  smaller  scale  agribusiness  enterprises  operate  outside  the  formal 
commercial  system,  suggests  that  the  solution  to  providing  increased  volumes  of  credit  to 
agribusiness  does  not  lie  in  simply  making  more  funds  available.  The  banking  subsector  in 
Pakistan  is  highly  liquid  at  present,  and  the  delivery  of  credit  to  the  private  sector  has  been 
increasing in recent years. The problem is one of market failure rather than a lack of funding. To 
address  this  issue,  efforts  need  to  focus  on  (i)  improving  enterprise  creditworthiness  and 
reducing the perceived level of risk faced by financial institutions in lending to agribusiness, and 
(ii) enhancing the capacity of financial institutions to identify agribusiness lending opportunities 
and to appraise and supervise agribusiness loans.  
 
2. 
Developing  financial  sector  policy  and  regulation  and  improving  access  to  credit 
information  relating  to  small  and  medium  enterprises  (SMEs)  are  already  being  addressed  by 
the Small and Medium Enterprise Sector Development Program (SMESDP). As the majority of 
agribusinesses to be supported under the proposed Project will be SMEs, further interventions 
in these areas by the Project are not considered necessary. While these steps will establish a 
more  favorable  environment  for  agribusiness  lending,  the  issue  remains  that  financial 
institutions  have  very  little  exposure  to  agribusiness.  The  SMESDP  is  addressing  financial 
institutions’  aversion  to  SME  lending  through  the  provision  of  consulting  services  to  enhance 
SME lending capacity and a partial credit guarantee (PCG) facility to address credit risk, thereby 
acting  as  a  catalyst  to  the  development  of  new  financial  products  for  SMEs  and  leveraging 
financial institutions’ existing funds to expand lending to SMEs. The SMESDP interventions are 
supervised by the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) because it has experience in this area and can 
act  more  independently  than  a  government  ministry  to  expedite  project  activities.  The  Project 
will  adopt  a  similar  approach  by  providing  capacity-building  support  for  participating  financial 
institutions  (PFIs)  encouraging  them  to  expand  lending  to  agribusiness,  supervised  by  SBP. 
Financial  institutions  eligible  for  the  PCG  will  also  be  supported  to  enable  them  to  access  the 
facility for agribusiness lending.  
 
While  support  for  capacity  building  to  increase  the  supply  of  agribusiness  finance  is 
3. 
clearly needed on the demand side, agribusiness support fund enterprise capacity building will 
enhance  the  technical,  managerial,  financial,  and  marketing  skills  of  potential  borrowers.  By 

 

 36 

          Appendix 5 

addressing  the  perception  among  management  of  financial  institutions  that  agribusiness 
practitioners  are  not  well  qualified,  the  Project's  agribusiness  support  fund  will  complement 
activities in agribusiness finance development. 
 
B. 

Agribusiness Finance Capacity Building 

4. 
The Project will provide support in two phases, first in awareness building, and second, 
in  customized  consulting  services  for  PFIs  in  agribusiness  finance.  Given  concerns  over 
confidentiality and conflict of interest, all contact with financial institutions will be conducted in-
house. Therefore, seminars or workshops with participants from multiple financial institutions will 
not  be  conducted  as  part  of  the  awareness  building  campaign.  SBP  will  be  the  Implementing 
Agency  for  this  component.  It  will  be  responsible  for  selecting  and  recruiting  consultants  and 
monitoring  their  performance  (through  the  use  of  international  consultants),  defining  PFI 
eligibility  criteria,  disbursing  project  funds  for  payment  of  consultants,  and  preparing  accounts 
and  reports  to  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  on  the  implementation  of  the  agribusiness 
finance capacity-building component. 
 

1. 

Awareness Building 

 
5. 
The  first  phase  will  involve  the  identification  of  private  sector  financial  institutions 
(predominantly commercial banks but possibly leasing companies) that have already developed 
or express an interest in SME or agribusiness lending. During project preparation, 14 financial 
institutions  were  consulted,  of  which  8  commercial  banks  and  2  microfinance  institutions 
expressed an interest in increasing their lending to agribusiness with project assistance.1 Some 
of the banks are already seeking to increase their lending products to small-scale agribusiness, 
and are prepared to submit business development plans that could be supported by the Project. 
A senior financial or banking consultant will be contracted for 3 person-months to undertake this 
phase.  The  consultant  will  make  a  series  of  presentations  to  senior  management  of  selected 
financial  institutions  to  build  their  awareness  of  the  agribusiness  subsector  as  a  potential 
market,  and  to  discuss  broad  proposals  relating  to  developing  a  strategy  and  approach  to 
establishing  or  expanding  agribusiness  lending.  The  consultant,  in  collaboration  with  SBP,  will 
identify a shortlist of financial institutions each of which will prepare a detailed strategy and work 
plan  for  introducing  and  expanding  agribusiness  lending.  Based  on  the  assessment  by  the 
awareness-building  consultants,  in  collaboration  with  appropriate  project  staff  and  SBP,  of  the 
eligibility,2 level of commitment of each PFI, and the quality of their proposed lending strategy, 
3–5 PFIs will be selected to receive customized capacity-building support. The level of support 
provided to each PFI will be dependent upon the PFI’s perceived needs. Subject to the financial 
institution  impact  monitoring  experience  of  SBP,  the  awareness-building  consultant  will  also 
provide  advice  to  the  monitoring  and  evaluation  consultants  of  the  project  management  unit 
(PMU)  on  appropriate  agribusiness  finance  development  impact  monitoring  indicators  to  be 
included in the project performance monitoring system.

AGRIBUSINESS POLICY AND ENABLING ENVIRONMENT DEVELOPMENT 

Agribusiness Policy Development 

A. 
 
One  of  the  constraints  highlighted  in  project  preparation  workshops  and  stakeholder 
1. 
feedback  was  the  lack  of  a  central  or  federal  agribusiness  policy  and  provincial  horticultural 
policies.  The  direction  and  stability  of  the  policy  environment  is  important  to  both  existing  and 
potential  agribusinesses.  Any  policy  must  provide  stability  and  an  effective  and  realistic  time 
horizon.  The  policies  will  reflect  the  Government’s  objective  of  encouraging  and  facilitating 
sustainable agribusiness development and horticultural production. 
  

1. 

National Agribusiness Policy Background and Rationale 

 
2. 
A national agribusiness policy is required to (i) promote and encourage enterprise start-
up and expansion, value chain integration, and product specialization; and (ii) determine ways 
to incorporate the informal sector into the agribusiness mainstream. The agribusiness subsector 
requires  support  in  a  number  of  ways  including  (i)  incentives  for  company  start-ups;  (ii) 
enterprise zones in areas with a product-based comparative advantage; (iii) government support 
for  achieving  value  chain  integration  through  outgrower  schemes;  (iv)  fast  track  export 
facilitation  and  standards  readiness,  (v)  measures  to  incorporate  the  informal  sector  into 
mainstream  agribusiness,  so  that  small  agribusinesses  can  benefit  from  the  opportunities  that 
exist  in  the  market  place;  (vi)  and  a  review  of  taxation  regulations  on  horticultural  products, 
particularly fruit juices. The country will require an agribusiness policy at the macro level so that 
all stakeholders in the country are aware of their responsibilities and obligations.  
 
3. 
Task Force. A policy will be formulated utilizing the services of a task force, nominated 
by  the  project  management  unit  (PMU)  and  approved  by  the  project  steering  committee.  The 
agribusiness task force will be constituted with both private and public sector members, with a 
maximum of two  members nominated from each sector and an international advisor acting as 
chairperson. The members will be provided with an honorarium, per diem, and travel allowance 
for the time spent working with the task force. To prepare the policy, the task force will gauge 
the  views  of  all  stakeholders  within  the  sector  over  4  months,  through  formal  and  informal 
discussions, and workshops.  The purpose of the agribusiness policy will be to (i) establish the 
definition and vision of agribusiness; (ii) determine institutional involvement and capabilities; (iii) 
prepare aims and objectives that include subsectors and products for growth and prioritization; 
(iv)  delineate  the  focus  of  Government  support  through  policy  reforms  and  targeted 
for  an  enabling  agribusiness 
interventions,  policy  stability  measures,  and  safeguards 
environment;  (v)  address  and  identify  demand-side  agribusiness  concerns  including  the 
business environment, required taxation regulation review, tax incentives, access to credit, and 
competitiveness;  (vi)  prepare  an  action  plan  for  implementing  the  strategy,  identifying  key 
indicators or targets and time horizons; (vii) identify measures to attain policy consistency and 
commitment; and (viii) identify other priority issues. 
 
4. 
Developing  an  Agribusiness  Policy.  The  policy  will  be  developed  over  a  year.  In 
chronological  order  the  activities  include  (i)  task  force  identification  and  constitution,  (ii) 
stakeholder discussions and policy preparation, (iii) policy submission, (iv) policy feedback and 
review  by  key  stakeholders,  and  (v)  policy  and  action  plan  approval  by  government  within  18 
months from project start-up.  
 
5. 
Consulting Services. The PMU will recruit an international agribusiness policy advisor. 
The advisor will be mobilized within the first 3 months of the implementation period for 6 person-

2. 

Provincial  and  Special  Area  Horticultural  Policies  Background  and 
Rationale 

6. 
Horticulture and its products are generally regarded as a minor subsector. Horticulture is 
not  considered  an  industry,  and  is  not  given  due  priority  and  emphasis  as  a  potential  income 
generator  in  rural  areas.  Horticulture  production,  and  cropping  profiles  and  seasons  vary 
between areas; each province and special area is distinct and needs its own policy tailored to its 
agro  climate,  cropping,  and  production  profiles.  The  Pakistan  Horticulture  Development  and 
Export Board already has the mandate to help formulate and implement the national horticulture 
policy, which is in the process of preparation.  
 
7. 
Provincial  and  special  area  policy  emphasis  will  be  placed  on  (i)  promotion  of  greater 
participation of the private sector, and the convergence of programs and projects implemented 
by  various  developmental  agencies  and  government  departments;  (ii)  policy  definition  and 
vision;  (iii)  institutional  involvement  and  capabilities;  (iv)  aims  and  objectives  that  include 
subsectors  and  products  for  growth,  and  prioritization  based  on  comparative  advantage  and 
inherent  production  and  marketing  skills;  (v)  focus  on  government  support  on  policy  reforms, 
and  targeted  interventions  such  as  policy  stability  measures  and  safeguards  to  create  an 
enabling horticultural subsector environment; (vi) preparation of an action plan for implementing 
the strategy, with key indicators or targets specified with time horizons; and (vii) determination of 
required institutional support and legislation. 
 
8. 
Task Force. The Project will establish provincial and special area policy task forces to 
liaise  with  the  Pakistan  Horticulture  Development  and  Export  Board  to  develop  horticultural 
policies in Balochistan, Punjab, and Sindh provinces, and special areas; and review the North-
West Frontier Province policy that has been prepared and is still in the process of being revised. 
Provincial  and  special  area  horticultural  task  forces  will  consist  of  five  members,  two 
representatives from the public sector, and three from the private sector (which may include a 
member from the Pakistan Horticulture Development and Export Board).  
 
9. 
Consulting Services. The PMU will recruit a national horticulture policy advisor who will 
be mobilized within the first 6 months of project implementation for two assignments of 10.5 and 
3.5  person-months  in  the  first  2  years  of  the  Project.  The  advisor  will  have  expertise  in  policy 
formulation with particular experience in horticultural policy. The advisor will

assist the PMU in recommending the complement and profile of the horticultural

manage the task forces to achieve their objectives of preparing the draft policy,

Enabling Environment Development and International Standards Compliance 

B. 

1. 

Background and Rationale 

During  1994,  Pakistan  signed  a  number  of  agreements  with  the  World  Trade 
10. 
Organization  (WTO)  that  relate  partly  or  wholly  to  food,  agriculture,  and  livestock.  The 
agreements  included  the  agreements  on  agriculture,  sanitary  and  phytosanitary  measures 
(SPS),  technical  barriers  to  trade,  and  trade-related  intellectual  property  rights.  Pakistan  as  a 
signatory is committed to implement and become compliant with these agreements. 

11. 
Developed  countries  have  prepared  and  enforced  stringent  standards  and  quality 
requirements  for  all  foodstuffs,  in  accordance  with  SPS  and  technical  barriers  to  trade,  to 
counter  the  import  of  substandard  poor  quality  food  and  ingredients.  Countries  that  export  to 
developed, and even developing markets, have to comply with, and harmonize their standards 
accordingly.  Implementation  of  the  agreements  and  conformity  with  standards  is  not  an  easy 
task. However, if Pakistan’s food exports do not comply with the new standards, they will lose 
their traditional markets as regulations become more stringent. Existing laws that are relevant to 
WTO agreements need to be amended, and capacity and knowledge of the agreements for all 
players  in  the  agribusiness  subsector  needs  to  be  strengthened.  To  comply  with  the  SPS 
agreement  the  Government  is  in  the  process  of  amending  a  number  of  laws  and  acts  before 
WTO regime enforcement.1  

2. 

Project Support 

12. 
The  Project  will  provide  assistance  in  a  number  of  areas  to  strengthen  the  regulatory 
framework, and international compliance and certification. Activities will include (i) assisting the 
WTO  cell  in  the  Ministry  of  Food,  Agriculture,  and  Livestock  (MINFAL)  to  expedite  the 
amendment  of  the  laws  and  acts  related  to  the  WTO  agreements;  (ii)  collating  and 
disseminating international standards information to the relevant stakeholders in both the private 
and  public  sectors,  through  the  Project's  capacity-building  component;  (iii)  coordinating  with 
other  trade  related,  WTO  capacity-building  projects  in  MINFAL,  Ministry  of  Commerce,  and 
Ministry  of  Industry  to  avoid  duplication  of  activities;  and  (iv)  helping  strengthen  and  promote 
improved food standards, and hazard analysis critical control point certification. The Project will 

                                                 
1  (i)  Pakistan  Plant  Quarantine  Act  (1976),  (ii)  Federal  Seed  Certification  Act  (1976),  (iii)  Agricultural  Produce 
(Grading  &  Marketing)  Act  (1937),  and  (iv)  Pakistan  Animal  Quarantine  (Import  &  Export  of  Animals  and  their 
Products) Act (1985).

recruit  a  national  policy,  institutional,  and  regulatory  advisor  to  the  PMU  for  the  first  3  project 
years  to  work  closely  with  the  PMU  project  director  and  advise  on  policy  institutional  and 
regulatory  framework  issues  that  affect  agribusiness.  The  advisor  will  assist  the  regulatory 
framework and compliance specialist to bring about necessary amendments in laws to conform 
with WTO regulations and agreements relating to agribusiness.

consultation with MINFAL. The consultant will

MINFAL Departmental Coordination 

1. 

Background and Rationale 

The country has no agribusiness coordination. There is a WTO cell in the economic wing 
14. 
of  MINFAL.  The  Department  of  Agriculture  and  Livestock  Product  Marketing  and  Grading  has 
the  responsibility  for  providing  market  information,  and  product  uniformity  and  quality  through 
grading standards. WTO activities need to be better coordinated by institutional restructuring.

undertaking an assessment of the capability and capacity of the relevant MINFAL WTO cells to 
make  recommendations  regarding  achieving  better  coordination  between  them,  or  possible 
restructuring measures that need to be undertaken.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 

A. 

Background 

Given  the  generally  low  level  of  capacity  in  agribusiness,  the  Project  requires  a 
1. 
significant input of consulting services both at the institutional and enterprise levels. Given the 
need to enhance Pakistan’s agribusiness quality standards to international levels, the innovative 
nature  of  the  Agribusiness  Support  Fund  (ASF),  and  the  Project’s  approach  to  agribusiness 
finance  development,  a  major  part  of  consulting  services  will  be  provided  by  international 
consultants. A total of 221 person-months of international and 128 person-months of domestic 
consulting  inputs  will  be  financed  under  the  Project.  A  high  degree  of  flexibility  will  be  written 
into each consulting contract to allow implementing agencies to recruit consultants according to 
needs determined as project implementation proceeds. 

Agribusiness Finance Development 

Agribusiness Support Service Provision 

B. 
 
International  and  domestic  consultants  will  be  engaged  at  the  start  of  project 
2. 
implementation to prepare and implement a nationwide promotion campaign for the ASF. Given 
the innovative nature of the ASF within the agriculture sector in Pakistan and the need for sound 
governance and management to ensure effective delivery of ASF funding, the ASF manager will 
be  recruited  as  an  international  consultant  for  the  duration  of  the  Project.  The  consultant  will 
initially  be  responsible  for  incorporating  and  establishing  the  ASF,  preparing  a  business  plan 
and operating procedures, and coordinating the promotion campaign. Thereafter, the consultant 
will be responsible for day-to-day management of the ASF and evaluating funding applications. 
 
C. 
 
3. 
Since  the  financing  of  agribusiness  of  the  type  to  be  supported  by  the  Project  is  very 
limited in Pakistan at present, agribusiness finance development consultants will all be recruited 
internationally.  The  first  phase  will  involve  a  program  of  awareness  building  within  potential 
participating  financial  institutions  (PFIs)  to  discuss  with  them  on  a  one-to-one  basis  the 
constraints  and  opportunities  for  agribusiness  finance  development.  These  discussions  will 
result  in  the  preparation  of  a  shortlist  of  PFIs  that  demonstrate  a  commitment  to  developing 
agribusiness lending with the support of the Project. From the shortlist, 3–5 PFIs will be selected 
for  the  second,  capacity-building  phase.  In  the  capacity-building  phase,  separate  teams  of 
consultants  will  work  with  individual  PFIs  to  avoid  issues  of  confidentiality  and  conflict  of 
interest, and will negotiate individual contracts with the State Bank of Pakistan, and subsidiary 
agreements with the PFI they support. Consultants will review business plans for agribusiness 
finance development prepared by the selected PFIs. Based on a strategy and work plan (with 
performance  targets  and  evaluation  criteria)  agreed  with  the  PFI  management,  they  will 
establish an agribusiness lending unit within the PFI. Consultants will support the unit for up to 
36  months,  during  which  time  they  will  develop  loan  products,  prepare  operating  procedures 
and manuals, and train PFI staff. At the end of the assignment, each PFI will have an operating 
agribusiness finance unit that it can take over and operate itself. The participation of PFIs in the 
Project is expected to be phased over the first 3 years of the Project.  
 
4. 
Throughout the implementation of the capacity-building phase, independent international 
consultants will monitor the performance of the international consultants in agribusiness finance 
development  in  each  PFI,  in  accordance  with  the  targets  agreed  with  each  PFI.  Contracts 
between  the  capacity-building  consultants  and  each  PFI  will  stipulate  actions  to  be  taken 
depending on the results of the performance monitoring review.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS

The  Project  seeks  to  support  the  contribution  of  agribusiness  to  economic  growth  and 
1. 
employment  generation  by  addressing  market 
facilitate  private-sector-led 
agribusiness  development  throughout  the  agribusiness  product  value  chain,  and  increasing 
institutional and market efficiencies by directly linking clients and service providers. This would 
be  achieved  by  extending  financial  and  technical  capacity-building  support  to  entrepreneurs, 
service  providers,  financial  institutions,  and  farmers;  and  improving  policy  and  regulatory 
frameworks.  The  Project  is  designed  to  (i)  support  agribusiness  development  to  contribute  to 
rural  growth  and  employment;  (ii)  provide  a  private  sector  focus  for  agricultural  diversification 
and export orientation; (iii) encourage enhanced public-private sector partnerships; (iv) improve 
the output of agricultural research and extension to make it more demand driven; (v) establish a 
network  of  quality  control  and  certification  laboratories;  and  (vi)  provide  capacity  building  on 
World  Trade  Organization  compliance  issues.  The  sector  analysis  in  Appendix  2  provides 
details  of  sectoral  constraints  and  issues,  lessons  learned,  and  opportunities  that  provide  the 
background for the project justification and analysis. 
 
B. 

Project Justification and Benefits 

2. 
The  need  for  the  Project  arises  from  (i)  current  market  failures  leading  to  inadequate 
financial  and  technical  support  to  the  private  sector  to  initiate  agribusiness  enterprises,  (ii) 
failures  in  institutional  capacity,  and  (iii)  the  absence  of  consistent  and  coherent  agribusiness 
policies. The Project will be a catalyst to improve the contribution of agribusiness to the national 
economy. It will encourage investment by the private sector in new or upgraded enterprises that 
have been constrained by limited financial and technical capacity and support. The Project will 
also  strengthen  institutions  to  formulate  policies  and  implement  a  regulatory  framework  in 
compliance  with  international  standards.  The  Project  is  designed  to  provide  benefits  to  all 
involved  in  the  value  chain,  including  landless  laborers;  fruit,  vegetable,  livestock,  and  dairy 
farmers;  support  industries;  service  providers;  financiers;  processors;  government  staff;  and 
consumers.  
 
3. 
The  focus  on  strengthening  private  sector  delivery  mechanisms  to  the  agribusiness 
subsector  throughout  the  value  chain  is  expected  to  (i)  increase  entrepreneurs’  capacity  to 
serve  increasingly  discerning  consumer  preferences,  (ii)  lead  to  greater  responsiveness  of 
institutions and market mechanisms to respond to farmers' and entrepreneurs’ needs, and (iii) 
as  a  result  lead  to  increases  in  efficiency  by  reducing  transaction  costs  and  increasing  the 
supply  of  services  demanded  by  agribusiness  clients.  Key  services  in  this  regard  will  be 
business  development  services, 
for  agribusiness  development,  agricultural  and 
agribusiness  training,  product  grading  and  marketing,  improved  seed  certification  and  quality, 
and  more  focused  agricultural  research  and  extension.  The  Project  will  improve  the 
agribusiness policy environment, institutional capacity, and service delivery in a comprehensive 
and systematic manner throughout the value chain to ensure that the project goal of supporting 
economic  growth  and  employment  generation  through  agribusiness  development  is  efficiently, 
effectively, and sustainably achieved. The deficiencies of the existing approaches are outlined in 
Appendix 2. In essence, the Project's approach will assist clients in the value chain to access 
needed  services  using  market-based  mechanisms,  and  to  improve  their  capacity  to  provide 
high-quality, higher-value-added products demanded by domestic and international markets.

these services. The fiscal impact of improved service delivery by the Government in areas such 
as  seed  certification,  product  grading  and  marketing,  regulatory  supervision,  and  policy

5.  
The  Project  will  also  support  improvements  to  ensure  quality  and  continuity  of  uniform 
raw material, without which value addition and marketing activities associated with agribusiness 
will  not  be  successful.  Farmers  and  raw  material  suppliers  will  not  only  be  supported  through 
agro-enterprise development support and training, but the Project will also support germ-plasm 
improvement  to  ensure  that  it  is  true  to  type,  uniform,  and  viable.  Development  of  new 
marketing channels and bringing together stakeholders in the value chain will be promoted by 
encouraging  processors,  packers,  and  distributors  to  work  with  farmer  groups  to  satisfy 
international standards and product traceability requirements.  
 
C. 

Methodology 

6. 
The  Project  will  support  a  wide  variety  of  demand-driven  interventions  identified  during 
implementation. As a result, the likely mix of the scale and types of interventions, and the overall 
project benefits cannot be accurately ascertained. Therefore, a full-scale cost-benefit analysis is 
considered impractical. The analysis is therefore based on a quantitative (financial) assessment 
of  selected  indicative  enterprises  that  could  be  implemented  by  the  private  sector  under  the 
Project, and an estimate of the number of direct and indirect beneficiaries of project support.  
 
The  assumptions  employed  in  the  preparation  of  indicative  model  budgets  and  their 
7. 
analysis  includes  (i)  all  cash  inflows  and  outflows  are  priced  at  constant  mid  2004  prices;  (ii) 
enterprise life is generally assumed as 20 years; (iii) the opportunity cost of capital used is 12%; 
(iv) general sales tax of 15% is applied to all enterprises except for those that are farm-based, 
and 10% income tax is adjusted from revenues; (v) increased production will have insignificant 
impact  on  the  prices,  as  the  main  benefits  are  qualitative  improvements  and  reduction  of 
postharvest  losses;  and  (vi)  entrepreneurs  will  finance  the  enterprises  themselves.  Model 
budgets were based on conservative cost and revenue estimates, and are based on the use of 
traditional  technologies,  rather  than  the  technologies  and  approaches  being  promoted  by  the 
Project. If project interventions are successful and allow producers and entrepreneurs to benefit 
from  an  improved  regulatory  framework,  improved  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  service 
provision,  and  access  to  finance  to  invest  in  improved  and  cost-efficient  processes  and 
technologies,  much  higher  returns  can  be  expected  (paras.  15–16).  The  detailed  feasibility 
studies  outline  the  critical  factors  that  need  to  be  monitored  to  ensure  success  of  the 
enterprises.  

 

D.

were found to be profitable and sustainable. Indicative agro-enterprises were analyzed for their 
financial viability and sensitivity analysis was undertaken. Results are in Table A12.1.

9. 
Seven of the enterprises are highly profitable, and exhibit relatively robust sensitivity to 
changes  in  benefits  or  costs.  The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  of  the  selected 
enterprises  ranges  between  12.3%  and  76.6%.  The  FIRRs  of  vegetable  seed  production  and 
marketing,  and  kinnow  pack  house  are  just  above  12%.  The  switching  values  for  these  two 
suggest  that  they  are  high-risk  investments.  Two  enterprises,  milk  collection  and  chilling 
centers, and mango-packing enterprise have reasonable FIRRs (28.6% and 18.2% respectively) 
but are sensitive to cost increases and decreases in benefits, and are medium risk investments. 
The  remaining  five  enterprises,  fruit  nursery  production,  livestock  fattening  yard,  cool  chain 
distribution  and  marketing  for  cut  flowers,  date  processing  plant,  and  cold  storage  have 
relatively  attractive  FIRRs,  and  are  not  sensitive  to  cost  increases  or  decreases  in  benefits. 
They are therefore financially robust and sustainable investments.

10. 
The  Project  will  have  a  wide  range  of  direct  and  indirect  beneficiaries.  Direct 
beneficiaries include farmers, landless laborers, market functionaries, processors and their staff 
and  workers,  and  other  related  entrepreneurs.  The  subsector  is  highly  labor  intensive  and 
provides  employment  to  a  large  number  of  skilled  and  unskilled  workers.  Expansion  in  the 
subsector and adoption of good practices is expected to foster an increase in labor demand and 
generate additional employment. Indirect beneficiaries include consumers, input suppliers, staff 
of government and project-related institutions, and service providers. 
 

1. 

Direct Beneficiaries 

11. 
The  direct  beneficiaries  during  the  project  life  would  include  male  and  female  faculty 
members  of  government  commerce  colleges,  and  vocational  training  institutes,  farmers, 
landless  laborers,  entrepreneurs,  employees  of  processors  and  packing  plants,  agribusiness 
service  providers,  and  financiers.  The  Project  will  provide  assistance  to  about  800  trainers  to 
acquire  skills  in  training  farmers  in  integrated  crop  and  pest  management,  and  to  serve  as  a 
resource  for  further  training.  In  addition,  the  Project  will  provide  training  to  500  extension 

 

 Appendix 12          55 

officers.  At  the  completion  of  the  Project,  about  25,000  farmers  will  have  been  trained  in 
improved farm production, integrated crop and pest management, and postharvest technology; 
140  persons  will  acquire  cut  flower  decoration  and  market  presentation  skills;  and  more  than 
3,000  workers  and  entrepreneurs  will  acquire  managerial,  processing,  and  total  quality 
management and international compliance skills; and 40 training institute and college managers 
and principals will be trained in management. An estimated 3,200 staff in federal, provincial, and 
special areas government service will be provided with agribusiness awareness training. 
 
Through the Agribusiness Support Fund (ASF), the Project will support beneficiaries through 
12. 
cost-sharing  grants  for  business  development  support,  agro-enterprise  start-ups,  farmer  group 
enterprise  formation,  demand-driven  research,  private-sector-led  extension  service;  and  help 
business  development  support  providers  to  enhance  their  capacity  in  the  agribusiness  subsector. 
The estimated grant value of $13.9 million will provide financial leverage of an additional $9.9 
million from grant recipients. The ASF in conjunction with 3–5 participating financial institutions 
(PFIs)  will  directly  enhance  agro-enterprise  competitiveness  and  productivity.  This  will  have  a 
positive  impact  on  enterprise  profitability,  and  lead  to  job  security  and  employment.  Following 
the awareness-raising and capacity-building activities of the PFIs, lending is expected to be at 
least  five  times  the  amount  leveraged  from  the  ASF.  This  could  benefit  an  additional  10,000 
agro-enterprises,  and  provide  significant  employment  and  income-generating  opportunities, 
conservatively  estimated  at  100,000  person-years  of  direct  employment,  and  700,000  person-
years of indirect employment.  
 
13. 
In  trying  to  estimate  the  potential  beneficiaries  from  the  indicative  agro-enterprises  that 
have  been  analyzed,  the  number  of  potential  beneficiaries  in  the  farming  community  is  high 
where enterprises rely on raw materials that are either produced on an intensive scale, or are 
reared  or  cultivated  by  small  farmers.  This  is  particularly  true  in  floriculture,  animal  fattening 
yards,  and  date  processing.  For  the  nine  agro-enterprises  identified,  raw  material  suppliers 
could  amount  to  about  4,500  growers  or  livestock  farmers.  Based  on  the  amount  of  ASF 
assistance  that  may  be  provided  to  agro-enterprises,  100,000  farmers  may  be  required  to 
provide products to those enterprises; of those 100,000 farmers, 12,500 will be associated with 
farmer agribusiness enterprises groups.  
 

2. 

Indirect Beneficiaries 

14. 
Indirect beneficiaries will include other farmers, who will benefit from certified vegetable 
seed  and  nursery  plants;  consumers  who  will  have  improved  access  to  quality  and  hygienic 
products; and service providers, for example, transporters, packing material suppliers, and farm 
input  and  processing  industry  input  suppliers.  Market  functionaries,  processors,  and  exporters 
will  benefit  from  qualitative  improvement  in  raw  unprocessed  supplies,  and  confidence  in 
investment in improved processing technologies and exploring international markets. 
 
F. 

Expected Project Impact 

15. 
For optimum project impact, interventions are tailored toward specialization in a range of 
products  to  which  limited  resources  can  be  channeled  to  make  a  significant  impact.  This  will 
lead to vertical integration in the value chain (from the field to the consumer) in production areas 
or  clusters  of  single  or  similar  types  of  products.  The  Project  will  support  specialization  in 
conjunction with quality improvement to achieve greater product comparative advantage.  
 
16. 
In  the  medium  term  (within  3  years  of  project  start-up),  an  environment  for  encouraging 
agribusiness  stakeholders  to  invest  in  agribusiness  is  expected  to  be  in  place,  leading  to  more 

 

 56          Appendix 12 

market outlets through an increase in the number of processing and packing units. Farmers are 
expected to be able to realize increases in net revenue, especially those who have diversified into 
more intensive (high-value crop) production. The creation of farmer marketing groups will result in 
improved  quality  and  packaging  resulting  in  a  minimum  10%  price  premium  on  selected 
products. Farmers are expected to be able to realize income increases by minimizing postharvest 
losses that amount to between 20–30% of the value of fruits and vegetables produced each year, 
or 2.7 million tons of products, with an estimated local market value of $522 million.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 

 
Agriculture  contributes  25%  to  the  gross  domestic  product—70%  toward  export  earnings—and  employs  48%  of  the 
labor  force.  Over  100  million  people,  68%  of  the  population,  live  in  rural  areas,  and  95%  earn  their  livelihood  from 
agriculture,  directly  or  indirectly.  Farmers,  laborers,  producers,  traders,  processors,  exporters,  and  various  service 
providers will benefit from the development of agro-enterprises promoted by the project components. Agribusiness has 
the potential to become a much more important source of economic growth and income generation, with small farmers 
as major beneficiaries. 
 
The  Poverty  Reduction  Partnership  Agreement  between  the  Government  of  Pakistan  and  the  Asian  Development 
Bank  (ADB)  signed  in  September  2002  focuses  on  support  for  poverty  reduction  measures.  In  this  agreement,  the 
medium-term strategy for agriculture and rural development is to “Increase agricultural productivity and diversification 
through  a  move  to  market-based  agricultural  prices  and  expansion  of  the  role  of  the  private  sector.”  The  Project 
contributes  to  the  medium-term  strategy  as  it  facilitates  the  development  of  private-sector-led  agribusinesses.  The 
project  interventions  include  (i)  agribusiness  policy  formulation  and  enabling  environment  development,  (ii) 
agribusiness capacity building, (iii) agribusiness support service provision, (iv) agribusiness finance development, and 
(v)  project  management  support  These  interventions  will  promote  production  diversification,  and  investment  in  agro-
enterprises, contributing to economic growth in the agriculture sector. The creation of an enabling policy environment, 
capacity  building,  and  the  provision  of  financing  for  agro-enterprises  will  result  in  the  development  of  small  and 
medium size agro-enterprises, and the creation of employment opportunities in rural areas. 

B. 

 
Poverty Analysis                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 

Pakistan  has  witnessed  a  worsening  poverty  situation  in  recent  years,  particularly,  in  rural  areas  where  39%  of  the 
population was living below the official poverty line in 2003. The Pakistan Economic Survey 2003/04 reported a 4.2% 
decline in poverty based on a small sample survey by the Federal Bureau of Statistics. The total population below the 
poverty  line  was  23%  at  the  national  level,  13.7%  in  urban  areas  and  28.4%  in  rural  areas.  Pakistan’s  human 
development index score is very low. It was ranked 144th on the Human Development Index with a score of 0.499 in 
2003.  In  2004,  its  rank  improved  to  142nd  but  its  score  on  the  Human  Development  Index  decreased  to  0.497.  The 
index is based on 2002 data when Pakistan had a life expectancy at birth of 60.7 years; adult literacy was 53.4% for 
males  and  28.6%  for  females;  and  combined  primary,  secondary,  and  tertiary  gross  enrolment  ratio  was  43%  for 
males and 31% for females.  

Low  levels  of  earnings  and  social  vulnerability  due  to  a  lack  of  access  to  health,  education,  water  supply,  and 
sanitation  facilities  characterize  poverty  in  Pakistan.  Lack  of  opportunities,  denial  of  basic  rights,  social  exclusion, 
corruption, manipulation of regulatory controls, and insecurity also characterize poverty. The poor have few physical 
assets, and rely disproportionately on informal sector jobs. Poverty characteristics include high levels of income and 
asset poverty, economic and social vulnerability, gender disparity, and low levels of human capital development. The 
distribution of land is highly skewed. The total farm area is 20.4 million hectares and the total number of landowning 
households is 6.6 million. Nearly 57.6% of the total ownership holdings are smaller than 2 hectares and account for 
15.5% of the total farm area. Only 1.6% of the landholdings are larger than 20 hectares, and account for 21.2% of the 
total  farm  area.  Concentration  of  land  owned  by  a  small  number  of  large  landholders  is  impoverishing  because  the 
poor have limited assets with which to work.  
The  Government  is  committed  to  reducing  the  incidence  of  poverty  to  below  15%  at  the  completion  of  the  10-Year 
Perspective Development Plan in 2011. The Government is committed to attaining the Millennium Development Goals 
by  2015.  The  economic  growth  rate  was  5.1%  in  FY2003  and  6.4%  in  FY2004,  and  in  the  past  5  years  cumulative 
spending  on  the  social  sector  and  poverty-related  programs  was  over  PRs860  billion.  The  project  components  will 
support increased investment in agribusiness production and processing, leading to economic growth that will reduce 
poverty  in  rural  areas.  The  development  of  agro-enterprises  will  contribute  to  economic  expansion,  and  create 
employment opportunities in both rural and urban areas that will also reduce poverty.

Participation Process 

C. 
Is there a stakeholder analysis? 
 
Is there a participation strategy?                
 
The  proposed  Project  will  encourage  the  organization  of  small  farmer  groups  to  establish  agro-enterprises.  Some 
nongovernment  organizations,  particularly,  rural  support  programs  (RSPs)  have  initiated  rural  development  activities 
with  community  participation.  RSPs  organize  small  community  groups,  mobilize  group  resources  to  build  financial 
capital,  and  provide  training  to  develop  skills  of  its  members.  RSPs  provide  microfinance  services  to  members  of 
community  organizations  without  collateral.  RSPs  can  organize  small  groups  of  farmers  interested  in  enterprise 
development.  The  Project  will  provide  support  to  RSPs  to  organize  specific  training,  and  business  development 
services needed for agro-enterprise development by small farmers. Agro-enterprise groups would borrow money from 
the  sponsor  RSPs  for  small  investments,  and  the  Project’s  agribusiness  support  fund  (ASF)  would  match  these 
amounts for eligible activities specified in the ASF component. Farmer agro-enterprise groups would not be recipients 
of  project  funds  for  capital  expenditure,  but  would  be  linked  to  the  Project  for  training  and  skills  enhancement. 
Sustainability of agro-enterprises is not linked to project support, but to the skills provided to the groups, and the funds 
that the groups borrow from the RSPs or financiers to operate the enterprise profitably.  
 

 

  

 

 

D. 

Gender Development 

Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Women  entrepreneurs  will  have  equal  opportunities  in  establishment  of  agro-enterprises,  and  in  access  to  project 
services.  Women  are  expected  to  obtain  training  and  employment  in  agro-enterprises.  An  improved  market  system 
with necessary mobilization and training will encourage the entry of women entrepreneurs into agribusiness. Increased 
access  among  the  women  will  require  more  women  staff,  which  will  improve  job  creation  for  women  and  empower 
them.
